questions.text: Haldane effect is _______

choices.text: Binding of O2 to Hb favours release of CO2
Binding of CO2 to Hb favours release of O2
HCO3- leaving RBC in exchange for Cl-

questions.solution:
Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect is called the Haldane effect. (Remember - Haldane effect occurs in lungs and causes left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Haldane Effect

  • Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This effect, called the Haldane effect, is important in promoting CO2 transport.
  • The Haldane effect results from the simple fact that the combination of O2 with hemoglobin in the lungs causes the hemoglobin to become a stronger acid. This displaces CO2 from the blood and into the alveoli.

questions.text: Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by_____
questions.solution:
Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by GLP-1.

Glucagon-like peptide–1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) are called incretins and are potent stimulators of insulin secretion. They also inhibit glucagon secretion. They are released in the gastrointestinal tract after a person eats a meal. They then cause an “anticipatory” increase in blood insulin in preparation for the glucose and amino acids to be absorbed from the meal. 

Note: Drugs that mimic the action of incretins are used in the management of diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR)?

choices.text: G proteins bind to hormones on the surface of the nucleus.
All the three subunits α, β, and ɣ should bind to each other for G proteins to act.
G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in α subunit.
G protein is bound to GTP in resting state.

questions.solution:
G proteins act as inhibitory or excitatory because of differences in α subunit.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times hence called seven helix or serpentine receptors.

G proteins have 3 subunits (α,β and ɣ). In its resting state, α subunit is bound to GDP.

Upon ligand binding to GPCR, it undergoes a conformational change that activates G protein within the cell. The α subunit dissociates and in turn alters the activity of second messengers such as cAMP, cGMP or Ca2+.

Once the ligand is unbound, the intrinsic GTPase activity of the α subunit converts GTP to GDP. This leads to reassociation of α with the β-ɣ subunit and termination of effector activation.

questions.text: Mitral cells are seen in ______
questions.solution:
Mitral cells are seen in Olfactory bulb.

Axons of Olfactory nerves (First cranial nerve) synapse with the mitral cells and tufted cells in the olfactory bulb to form anatomically discrete units called olfactory glomeruli.

The olfactory bulb also contains periglomerular cells that are inhibitory interneurons and granule cells that make reciprocal synapses with mitral and tufted cells.

These mitral and tufted cells (second-order neurons) terminate in Olfactory cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the Papez circuit?
questions.solution:
Anterior nucleus of the thalamus is a component of Papez circuit, which is important for short term memory.

Papez Circuit (refer figure):

The limbic system was studied by James Papez who described the Papez circuit. It consists of:

Mnemonic for components of Papez circuit-He Man Ate Cat

  • He-Hippocampus
  • Man-Mamillary body
  • Ate-Anterior thalamus
  • Cat-Cingulate gyrus

The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which are in turn connected to the anterior nuclei of the thalamus by the mammillothalamic tract. The anterior nuclei of the thalamus project to the cingulate cortex, and from there, connections to the hippocampus complete a complex closed circuit.

The boundaries of the limbic system were subsequently expanded to include the amygdala, septum, basal forebrain, nucleus accumbens, and orbitofrontal cortex.

questions.text: Which is the best parameter to analyze hypoxic hypoxia?

choices.text: Partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2)
Partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2)

questions.solution:
Hypoxic hypoxia is characterized by low partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood (Pao2), while other parameters like partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood (Paco2) may remain normal.

Ventilation–Perfusion Imbalance:

  • The patchy ventilation–perfusion imbalance is the most common cause of hypoxic hypoxia or hypoxemia.
  • If alveoli are not ventilated but perfusion is present - blood passing through that alveoli remains unoxygenated.
  • When this unoxygenated blood mixes with blood from normal or overventilated alveoli, there is a right to left shunt created.
  • This results in reduced partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood  (PaO2) i.e., hypoxemia and consequently hypoxia.

Note:

  • Hypoxemia can be defined as a condition where arterial oxygen tension or partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) is below normal.
  • Hypoxia is defined as the reduction of oxygen supply at the tissue level, which is not measured directly by a laboratory value.

Scenario 1:

  • Generally, the presence of hypoxemia suggests hypoxia i.e. if there is less oxygen in blood, O2 supply to tissues will also be reduced.
  • But, in case of cyanide poisoning, there is hypoxia in the absence of hypoxemia, i.e., arterial O2 content is normal but tissues are not able to utilize it because cyanide interferes with aerobic metabolism in the tissues.

Scenario 2:

  • Hypoxia may not be present in patients with hypoxemia if the patient compensates for a low PaO2 by increasing oxygen delivery. This is typically achieved by increasing cardiac output (by raising the heart rate) or decreasing tissue oxygen consumption.
  • Nevertheless, hypoxemia is definitely the most common cause of tissue hypoxia, and the correct diagnosis should be made because it is readily treatable.

questions.text: All of the following are rapidly acting blood pressure control mechanisms except:
questions.solution:
Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is not a rapidly acting pressure control mechanism, it is an intermediate-acting mechanism.

Regulation of Arterial Blood Pressure:

  • Rapidly acting pressure control mechanism (acting within sec or min)
    • The chemoreceptor reflex.
    • The central nervous system ischemic mechanism.
    • The baroreceptor reflex.
  • Intermediate-acting mechanisms (act after minutes)
    • The capillary fluid shift mechanism.
    • Stress-relaxation of the vasculature.
    • The renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism.
  • Long-term mechanisms (after days)
    • Renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)

Note:

  • Renin-angiotensin vasoconstrictor mechanism is an intermediate-acting mechanism, but water conservation by RAAS is a long-term mechanism in the regulation of BP.
  • Most rapidly acting: Baroreceptor reflex>>Chemoreceptor reflex

questions.text: How much urine in the bladder will cause the first urge to void in a patient?
questions.solution:
The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL, and a marked sense of fullness at about 400 mL.

Cystometrogram (refer figure)

A plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder is called a cystometrogram.

The curve shows

  • An initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced(Ia);
  • A long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced(Ib);
  • A sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered(II).
  • The flatness of segment Ib is a manifestation of the law of Laplace.
  • This law states that the pressure in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension divided by the radius.
  • P= 2T/R
  • In the case of the blad­der, the tension increases as the organ fill but so does the radius. Therefore, the pressure increase is slight until the organ is relatively full.

questions.text: The myogram below shows a slow onset and a longer after-discharge. Which type of reflex does it represent?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the typical myogram recorded from a muscle involved in a crossed extensor reflex. This myogram demonstrates the relatively long latency before the reflex begins and the long after-discharge at the end of the stimulus.

  • When a painful stimulus is applied to the body, the flexor withdrawal and the crossed extensor reflexes are stimulated.
  • About 0.2 to 0.5 seconds after the flexor reflex in one limb, the opposite limb begins to extend. This reflex is called the crossed extensor reflex.
  • After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has an even longer period of after-discharge than does the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

Compare the myograms of a flexor reflex with a crossed extensor reflex.

In the flexor reflex, the contraction occurs immediately after applying the stimulus and the after-discharge is smaller.

questions.text: In a patient, pO2 is 85mmHg, pCO2 is 50mmHg, pH is 7.2, and HCO3- is 36mmol/L. Identify the condition.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
This patient has respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

pH is decreased (<7.35) so it is acidosis.

The CO2 levels are increased (>45mmHg), which is in line with the change in pH (in respiratory acidosis CO2 is expected to raise), thus the primary problem is respiratory.

The HCO3- levels are increased (>30mmol/L), which is opposite to change in pH (i.e there is acidosis and HCO3- levels are high), thus, there is compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

Thus, this is a case of respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cell adhesion molecule (CAM)?
questions.solution:
Spectrin is a cytoskeletal protein but not a cell adhesion molecule.

Cells are attached to each other or to the basal lamina by cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). Some important classes of CAMs are: 

  • Integrins: heterodimers that bind to various receptors
  • IgG superfamily of immunoglobulins
  • Cadherins: Ca2+-dependent molecules that mediate cell-to-cell adhesion by homophilic reactions
  • Selectins which have lectin-like domains that bind carbohydrates

Clinical significance

  • Cancer cells have abnormal CAMs and hence cause decreased cell adhesion and allow individual cancer cells to detach from the parent cancer.
  • The decrease in the amount of E-cadherin maybe the reason for early metastasis of numerous tumors.

questions.text: The figure below depicts the major anatomical site of _______ neurons.
questions.solution:
Cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain complex project to the hippocampus and the neocortex and those in the pontomesencephalotegmental cholinergic complex project to the dorsal thalamus and the forebrain.

Major Anatomical Sites of Various Neuromodulators

  • Noradrenergic neurons in the locus coeruleus innervate the spinal cord, cerebellum, several nuclei of the hypothalamus, thalamus, basal telencephalon, and neocortex. (Figure A)
  • Serotonergic neurons in the raphe nuclei project to the hypothalamus, limbic system, neocortex, cerebellum, and spinal cord. (Figure B)

questions.text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron.  

Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” 

Option (b):

The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit.

Option (c):

A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure.

Option (d):

A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following equations is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for an ion?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium potential for an ion is calculated using the Nernst equation. 

When there is a concentration gradient for an ion across the membrane, the ion tends to diffuse down the concentration gradient. The electric potential that exactly opposes this net diffusion is called the equilibrium potential for that ion. This is calculated using the Nernst equation.

It is expressed as the potential inside the cell (intracellular potential relative to the extracellular potential).

To calculate the value of the equilibrium potential:

Note: In this formula, the choice of concentration of the ion placed in the numerator and denominator does not matter because the formula is only used to derive the numerical value and not the sign ( +/- ). Mathematically, log (100/10) = 1  and log (10/100) = - 1. Hence, changing the numerator and denominator only changes the sign and the numerical value remains the same.

This equation is used only to derive the numerical value of the potential. It is NOT used to derive the sign/charge (+/-).

The sign/charge is derived from logic:

  • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater outside, then the + ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively. Hence, the potential will be positive.
  • In a positive (+) ion, if the concentration of the + ion is greater inside, then the + ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively (as + ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be negative.
  • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater outside, then the - ion moves from outside to inside. The intracellular potential becomes more - relatively. Hence the potential will be negative.
  • In a negative (-) ion, if the concentration of the - ion is greater inside, then the - ion moves from inside to outside. The intracellular potential becomes more + relatively (as - ion moves outside). Hence the potential will be positive.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anandamide?

choices.text: There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray

questions.solution:
There are anandamide-containing neurons in the periaqueductal gray and other areas concerned with pain.

There are 2 types of endogenous cannabinoids: 2-arachidonyl glycerol and Anandamide. They bind to CB1 and CB2 receptors. They have an anti-nociceptive effect.

Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways. This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiates.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding dead space volume in a healthy individual?

choices.text: Anatomical dead space> physiologic dead space
Anatomical dead space< physiological dead space
Anatomical dead space and  physiologic dead space are almost equivalent
Anatomical dead space is not related to physiologic dead space

questions.solution:
In healthy individuals, anatomical dead space and physiologic dead space are almost equivalent, and can be estimated by body weight.

Dead space is the volume of the airways and lungs that do not participate in gas exchange.

Types

  • Anatomic dead space- Volume of the air-occupying conducting zone where no exchange of gases takes place.
  • Alveolar/functional dead space- the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood (wasted ventilation)
  • Total dead space/Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar dead space.

In healthy individuals:

  • Anatomical dead space = 150 mL.
  • Alveolar dead space is usually zero (increased in diseased conditions).

Hence,

  • Physiological dead space = Anatomical + Alveolar = 150 + 0 = 150 mL.
  • Physiological dead space = Anatomical dead space.
  • Radford's formula: Anatomical dead space in mL is approximately equal to the body weight in pounds.
  • Dead space can be measured by the following:
    • Single Breath N2 method (Fowler’s method)
    • Bohr’s equation

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and was prescribed ferrous fumarate tablets for 2 months. Which of the following channels help in the absorption of this iron taken orally into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
The channel that helps in the absorption of the iron into the enterocyte is divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Transport of iron across the brush border of the intestinal cells in the ferrous form is accomplished by DMT-1, also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp 2). 

The mechanism of iron absorption and transport - 

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. This iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1). 

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

questions.text: Which statement about the facilitated diffusion is true?
questions.solution:
When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Examples

  • GLUT
  • Urea Transporters :
    • UTA 1, 2, 3, 4 in Kidney
    • UTB in RBC
  • Amino Acid Transporters

Other options are wrong because: 

  • Facilitated diffusion is a type of passive transport.
  • It follows saturation kinetics. 
  • No energy input is required in facilitated diffusion.

questions.text: The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to _______ phase of the cardiac cycle.
questions.solution:
The x descent in jugular venous pressure corresponds to the ventricular systole of the cardiac cycle.

The jugular venous pulse

  • The waves in JVP reflect the pressure changes in the right atrium.
  • The internal jugular vein is preferred because the external jugular vein is valved and not directly in line with the superior vena cava and right atrium.
  • a wave: Corresponds to right atrial contraction.
  • c wave: Corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent: Corresponds to the atrial relaxation as the ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve during ejection.
  • v wave: Corresponds to the venous filling of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve.
  • y descent: Corresponds to fall in right atrial pressure during passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones demonstrates the fluctuations depicted below?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone demonstrates the depicted fluctuations. Growth hormone is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with increase during strenuous exercise and during the early period of sleep, (Non-REM Sleep) as shown in the graph. It is reduced during the later stages of sleep. (REM sleep)

Other options:

Option A: ACTH levels are high in the early morning and low in the late evening. 

Option C: TSH is secreted in pulses, but the fluctuations are less in comparison to other pituitary hormones because of the low amplitude of the pulses and the relatively long half-life of TSH.

Option D: Prolactin is secreted in a pulsatile fashion, with the highest secretory peak between 4:00 and 6:00 a.m. (REM Sleep)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has a resting heart rate of 70-beats/min. Her pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. What is her cardiac output (in mL/min)? (Point 2 corresponds to 120 ml)
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has a heart rate of 70-beats/min and the stroke volume can be determined from the given pressure-volume diagram.

Point 2 corresponds to the EDV(End diastolic volume) = 120 mL
Point 1 corresponds to the ESV(End systolic volume) = 50 mL

Thus, stroke volume (SV) = EDV – ESV = 120 – 50 = 70 mL

Therefore, Cardiac output = HR X SV = 70 X 70 = 4900 mL/min.

This is AIIMS pattern question. Detailed and thorough knowledge on cardiac cycle, pressures and volumes is a must for any entrance exam as it a frequently tested topic.

questions.text: Which of the following cells secrete anti mullerian hormone?
questions.solution:
(Anti Mullerian Hormone) is secreted by both sertoli cells and granulosa cells.

Sertoli cells produce Anti Mullerian Hormone (Mullerian inhibitory substance) during development. It induces the regression of the mullerian duct that is programmed to give rise to a female reproductive tract.

Granulosa cells of the ovary produce AMH during the reproductive years. It limits the formation of primary follicles by inhibiting excessive follicular recruitment by FSH.

questions.text: A professional athlete uses phosphocreatine to improve his sprinting capacity and maximize muscle power during a 100 m dash race. Which of the following energy systems is utilized by the muscles of the athlete's body during a dash race?
questions.solution:
The phosphagen system is utilized by the muscles of the athlete's body during a dash race.

The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run. Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

Energy systems:

  • The phosphocreatine-creatine system: The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These substances together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds.
  • The glycogen–lactic acid system: can provide 1.3 to 1.6 minutes of maximal muscle activity.
  • The aerobic system: The aerobic system is the oxidation of foodstuffs in the mitochondria to provide energy. It can sustain mucle activity for an unlimited time (as long as nutrients last).

Phosphocreatine is used intravenously in hospitals in some parts of the world for cardiovascular problems under the name Neoton, and also used by some professional athletes, as it is not a controlled substance.

questions.text: The diagram below shows the pressure-volume curves for 3 different lungs. Which of the following is the best representation of compliance between the three lungs?
questions.solution:
• The pressure-volume relationship is the fundamental relation between the work of breathing and lung mechanics.
  • The diagram depicts the change in volume with respect to the change in intrapleural pressure, which is compliance. Here, the change is more (steep curve) with B and least (flat curve) with C. 
  • The “stiffer” lung displays a more horizontal curve (C), meaning that it takes a greater pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared with a normal lung (A). These lungs are called less compliant.
  • Curve (B) is more compliant as it takes lesser pressure to achieve the same inflation volume compared to normal (A).

Applied aspect:

Compliance is increased in emphysema. The mechanism is shown in the flow chart below.

Compliance is decreased in case of pulmonary edema or fibrosis.

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding smooth muscle is false?

choices.text: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential
Dense Bodies are present instead of Z lines
It can exert a variable tension at any given length
Sympathetic stimulation produces excitatory membrane potentials

questions.solution:
Sympathetic stimulation (norepinephrine) of a smooth muscle produces inhibitory potentials and relaxation.

Parasympathetic stimulation (or acetylcholine) causes depolarization and contraction in the smooth muscle.

Smooth muscle can be divided into:

  • Unitary smooth muscle - has low-resistance gap junctions between individual muscle cells and functions in a syncytial manner
  • Multiunit smooth muscle -  made up of individual units with few or nil gap junctions.

Blood vessels have both unitary and multiunit smooth muscle in their walls.

Option A: Unitary smooth muscle has an unstable membrane potential with continuous irregular contractions independent of its nerve supply. This state of partial contraction is called tonus or tone.

Option B: Dense bodies are present instead of Z lines in smooth muscle. These are bound to actin filaments by α-actinin.

Option C: Smooth muscle can exert variable tension at any given length. This property is called plasticity. When a unitary smooth muscle is stretched, it first exerts increased tension. However, if it is held at this length after stretching, the tension gradually decreases. This is referred to as plasticity.

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure is______

choices.text: Negative at apex but positive at base

questions.solution:
Intrapleural pressure is usually negative. (normally -2.5 mmHg)

During inspiration, it becomes more negative. (-6 mmHg). 

During forced expiration, contraction of the expiratory muscles raises intrapleural pressure to a positive value.

Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the visceral and parietal pleura.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are primarily sensitive to_____
questions.solution:
The peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid and aortic bodies, are primarily sensitive to decrease in arterial PO2, although high PaCO2 and low pH also stimulates them and enhance their sensitivity to hypoxia.

Carotid body is more sensitive than aortic body.

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except ______

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the ɣ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.solution:
In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all muscles of the body).

Decerebration

  • Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is called a mid-collicular decerebration.
  • This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities.
  • The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) remain intact.
  • The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called decerebrate rigidity.
  • The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates γ-motor neurons which indirectly activate α-motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop.

Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.text: A patient sustains an injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere. Loss of sensation is likely to be seen at which of the following sites in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, injury to the lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus in the right hemisphere would result in loss of sensation in the left facial area.

Each hemisphere receives somatic sensory information from the opposite side of the body in the postcentral gyrus (somatosensory area).

The lateral portion of the postcentral gyrus receives somatic sensory information from the facial and neck region while the medial portion of the postcentral gyrus received somatic sensory information from the trunk and appendages.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line)?
questions.solution:
Curve C corresponds to blood from an adult (dark blue line) and blood from a fetus (light blue line). The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is shifted to the left relative to the adult curve.

The fetal hemoglobin (Hb F) has a greater affinity for O2 than adult hemoglobin (Hb A). This facilitates the movement of O2 from the mother to fetus. The cause of this greater affinity is the poor binding of 2,3-DPG by ɣ polypeptide chains that replace β chains in Hb F. The fetal oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve is thus shifted to the left relative to the adult curve. Typically, fetal arterial Po2 is low, hence leftward shift enhances placental uptake of O2.
